input: For the molecule identified as CC(=O)OCC12CC(OC(=O)CC(C)C)C(C)=CC1OC1C(O)C(OC(C)=O)C2(C)C12CO2, what is its Average Daily Intake?
output: The molecule is mycotoxins, harmful substances produced by fungi in several commodities with a widespread presence in foodstuffs. Human exposure to mycotoxins occurs mainly by contaminated food. The quantitation of mycotoxins in cereal-based food, highly consumed by different age population, is of concern. In this survey, 159 cereal-based samples classified as wheat, maize and rice-based, have been evaluated for the occurrence of patulin, deoxynivalenol, 3-acetyl-deoxynivalenol, fusarenon-X, diacetoxyscirpenol, nivalenol, neosolaniol, HT-2, T-2 and zearalenone by gas chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry. Intakes were calculated for average consumers among adults, children and infants and compared with the tolerable daily intakes (TDI). Data obtained were used to estimate the potential exposure levels. 65.4% of the samples were contaminated with at least one mycotoxin and 15.7% of the analyzed samples showed co-occurrence of mycotoxin. The dietary exposure to HT-2 and T-2 toxins was estimated as 0.010 and 0.086 ugkg-1bwd-1, amounting to 10% and 86% of the TDI, for adults and infants respectively. These results back up the necessity to take a vigilant attitude in order to minimize human intake of mycotoxins.

DDE was detected in 100% of human breast milk samples from mothers of 62 boys with cryptorchidism and mothers of 68 healthy boys in Finland and Denmark from 1997-2001, with median concns (ranges) of 97.32 (21.77-427.55) and 83.76 (18.95-377.49) ng/g lipid, respectively.

input: Can you indicate the Body Burden for the molecule O=C(c1ccccc1)c1ccccc1?
output: The molecule is a benzophenone (BP)-type UV filter (i.e., sunscreen compound). In this study, we determined the concentrations of five BP derivatives, BP-1, BP-2, BP-3, BP-8, and 4OH-BP in urine (n = 101) as well as paired specimens of blood and urine (n = 24 pairs) collected from adults; in matched maternal and fetal cord blood (n = 20 pairs) collected from pregnant women; and in blood collected from children (n = 10). 4OH-BP, BP-1, and BP-3 were found in 61%, 57%, and 25%, respectively, of the urine samples analyzed. 4OH-BP was found in all blood samples; BP-3 was found more frequently in the blood of adults (83%), followed, in decreasing order, by pregnant women (35%) and children (30%). Among all adults, urinary BP-3 concentrations were significantly (p < 0.001) positively correlated with urinary BP-1 concentrations. Nevertheless, no significant correlations were found between urinary concentrations of BP-3 (or BP-1) and 4OH-BP. Our results suggest that human exposure to BP-3 and BP-1 is related, whereas 4OH-BP originates from a discrete source. Females had higher urinary concentrations of BP-3, BP-1 and 4OH-BP than males. The distribution profiles of BP-1 and its parent compound (i.e., BP-3) in urine decreased with increasing age of donors (p < 0.05). The ratio of concentrations of BP-3 between blood and urine was 0.21 in adults, which was significantly lower than that for 4OH-BP (0.36). The concentration ratio of BPs between cord blood and maternal blood was higher for 4OH-BP (0.61) than that for BP-3 (0.48), which suggested greater trans-placental transfer potential of 4OH-BP. This is the first study to document the occurrence of BPs in paired urine and blood, and in matched maternal and fetal cord blood.

input: What is the Body Burden associated with the molecule QKSKPIVNLNLAAV-UHFFFAOYSA-N?
output: The molecule is bis(2-chloroethyl) sulfide. Levels were detected in the urine of 6 out of 12 patients from the Iran-Iraq War (1986) ranging from 1-30 ppb. The same authors had previously identified 1 and 1.5 ppb of bis(2-chloroethyl)sulfide in the urine of two other patients from the Iran-Iraq War. Concentrations three orders of magnitude greater than the above have been found in fat and fat-rich organs such as the brain and these are thought to act as a reservoir for a very low concentration of bis(2-chloroethyl)sulfide in the urine. Urine samples taken from 9 Iranian patients, victims of an alleged attack by chemical warfare agents, contained 4-110 and 15-90 ng/mL of thiodiglycol, a hydrolysis product of bis(2-chloroethyl)sulfide. A 1985 autopsy of body tissue and fluids of an Iranian man who had died 7 days after exposure to mustard gas resulted in the following concentrations (tissue - concentration in ppm wet weight): brain 10.7; cerebrospinal fluid 1.9; liver 2.4; kidney 5.6; spleen 1.5; lung 0.8; muscle 3.9; fat 15.1; skin 8.4; skin with subcutaneous fatty tissue 11.8; blood 1.1; urine below detection limit of approximately 0.1 ppm.

input: What is the Body Burden of the molecule called CNCCC(Oc1ccc(C(F)(F)F)cc1)c1ccccc1.Cl?
output: The molecule is fluoxetine (range 20-252 ug/L) detected in five of the nine infants from whom plasma samples were collected, and norfluoxetine (range 17-187 ug/L) detected in seven of the nine infants. Mothers of these infants were being treated with fluoxetine for depression. The highest of these concentrations was about 70% of the maternal plasma concentrations. The mean combined dose of fluoxetine and norfluoxetine transmitted to infants via breast milk is below the 10% national level of concern. However, there was considerable interpatient variability in estimated infant dose and in some of the patients, the dose was >10%. Further, since adverse effects have been observed in breast-fed infants, careful monitoring of the infants is mandatory. Neonates exposed to these drugs in utero had higher concentrations of fluoxetine and norfluoxetine and are at greater risk of adverse effects.

It was also detected in five of 65 human sera samples obtained from US biological supply companies at concentrations of 1.5 to 2.2 ppb. It was not detected (detection limit 0.7 ng/mL) in two human milk samples, collection information was not provided. Perfluorooctanesulfonamide concentrations in human sera were <1.3-23.5 and 1.3-26 ng/mL in samples from Michigan and Kentucky.

input: I would like to know the Disposal Methods of the molecule referred to as CCC(CC)C(=O)OCCOCCOCCOC(=O)C(CC)CC.

The molecule is a waste sludge, specifically a byproduct of industrial processes such as chemical manufacturing, paper production, and waste recycling. The sludge is composed of various organic and inorganic components, including nutrients, minerals, and contaminants, such as heavy metals, organic acids, and organic compounds.
The disposal method for waste sludge is crucial to ensure environmental safety and minimize the risk of pollution. The primary disposal method for waste sludge is land treatment or burial, which involves the following steps:

1. Collection: Waste sludge is collected from various sources, including industrial facilities, landfills, and waste treatment plants. The collection process may involve the use of trucks, excavators, or other equipment to transport the sludge to a designated disposal site.
2. Pre-treatment: Before disposal, waste sludge is typically pre-treated to remove contaminants, such as organic acids, heavy metals, and organic compounds, that may pose a risk to human health and the environment. This may involve chemical treatment, physical separation, or biological treatment methods.
3. Treatment: The pre-treatment steps are followed by a series of treatment processes, including chemical treatment, physical separation, or biological treatment, depending on the specific sludge characteristics and the desired disposal outcome. The treatment process may involve the addition of chemicals, such as acids, alkalis, or enzymes, to break down the organic components of the sludge and remove hazardous substances.
4. Drying: After treatment, the sludge is dried to remove moisture and reduce the volume of the waste. This may involve the use of heat, vacuum, or other drying techniques, depending on the specific conditions and the desired disposal outcome.
5. Land disposal: The dried waste is then transported to a designated disposal site, such as a sanitary landfill or a waste-to-energy facility. The disposal site is designed to meet environmental standards for land treatment and burial, including the use of appropriate liners, leachate collection systems, and monitoring of environmental conditions.
6. Monitoring and evaluation: The disposal site is monitored regularly to ensure that the waste is being treated and disposed of safely and efficiently. This may involve the collection of data on the sludge's composition, moisture content, and environmental conditions, as well as the monitoring of any potential health or environmental risks.
7. Disposal alternatives: In some cases, alternative disposal methods may be considered for waste sludge, such as incineration, composting, or anaerobic digestion. These methods may be more environmentally friendly or cost-effective than land treatment or burial, but they may also have different disposal requirements and limitations.
8. Regulatory compliance: The disposal of waste sludge is subject to regulatory guidelines and standards, including those related to environmental protection, waste management, and hazardous waste disposal. Compliance with these guidelines is essential to ensure that the waste is disposed of safely and efficiently, minimizing the risk of pollution and environmental damage.

In summary, the waste sludge is a complex and challenging waste management issue that requires careful consideration of its composition, treatment, and disposal methods. The primary disposal method for waste sludge is land treatment or burial, which involves the collection, pre-treatment, treatment, drying, and disposal of the waste at a designated disposal site. The disposal method is subject to significant revision and may involve alternative disposal methods, regulatory compliance, and ongoing monitoring and evaluation to ensure that the waste is being treated and disposed of safely and efficiently.

In the present study, the potential genotoxicity and immunotoxicity of three neonicotinoids (imidacloprid, nitenpyram, and dinotefuran) were assessed in Chinese rare minnows by using a 60-day chronic toxicity test. The hematological and biochemical parameters of juvenile Chinese rare minnows and changes in the transcription of six inflammation-related genes were determined after exposure to neonicotinoids at 0.1, 0.5, or 2.0 mg/L. A clear difference in the frequency of erythrocytes with micronuclei (MN) was observed after treatment with 2.0 mg/L imidacloprid (p<0.05). Additionally, exposure to 0.5 or 2.0 mg/L imidacloprid significantly increased the binucleated (BN) erythrocytes and those with notched nuclei (NT) (p<0.05). A serum protein electrophoresis (SPE) assay showed significant alterations in the serum protein in all treatments (p<0.05), and further analysis indicated decreases in immunoglobulin (Ig) in treatments with 0.5 or 2.0 mg/L imidacloprid or dinotefuran or with 0.1 mg/L nitenpyram (p<0.05). Moreover, a biochemical assay confirmed that immunoglobulin M (IgM) levels were indeed significantly decreased upon treatment with imidacloprid or dinotefuran at 0.5 or 2.0 mg/L (p<0.05). In addition, the transcriptional levels of the inflammatory cytokines IL-6, INF-alpha, TNF-alpha, and IL-1beta were markedly down-regulated after all imidacloprid treatments (p<0.05), whereas the expression levels of only TNF-alpha and IL-1beta were significantly down-regulated following the 0.5 and 2.0 mg/L dinotefuran treatments (p<0.05). Taken together, results clearly demonstrate that imidacloprid, rather than nitenpyram and dinotefuran, can induce genotoxicity. The responsiveness of these immune indicators provides new insight into and evidence of the adverse effects of neonicotinoids on aquatic non-target organisms.

output: The molecule studied were octyl-p-methoxycinnamate (OMC) also called 2-ethylhexyl-4-methoxycinnamate (EHMC); 4-methylbenzylidene camphor (4-MBC); benzophenone-3 (BP-3); 4-hidroxybenzophenone (4-HB); octocrylene (OC); and octyldimethyl-p-aminobenzoate (OD-PABA). Expression levels of the genes coding for the ecdysone receptor (EcR), the ultraspiracle (usp, ortholog of the RXR) and the estrogen-related receptor (ERR) were quantified by Real Time PCR after in vivo exposure at different dosages. The EcR gene was significantly upregulated by 4-MBC, OMC/EHMC and OD-PABA, with a dose-related response following 24 hr exposure. The benzophenones, BP-3 and 4-HB, as well as OC did not alter this gene at the same exposure conditions. The transcription profiles of the usp and ERR genes were not significantly affected, except for BP-3 that inhibited the usp gene at the highest concentration. This is the first experimental evidence in invertebrates of a direct effect of UV filters on endocrine-related genes, and is consistent with the known effects on vertebrate hormonal receptor genes. The capability of 4-MBC, OMC/EHMC and OD-PABA to stimulate the expression of the ecdysone receptor, a key transcription factor for the ecdysone-genomic response in arthropods, suggests the possibility of a broad and long-term effect on this hormonal pathway. These findings strengthen the need for further research about the ecotoxicological implications of chronic exposure to these compounds in aquatic invertebrates.

Posttreatment uric acid, aspartate aminotransferase, lactic dehydrogenase, and gamma glutamyltransferase increased as compared with pretreatment values. In contrast, posttreatment plasma total protein, cholesterol, and triglyceride levels numerically decreased as compared with pretreatment values. output: The molecule growth-inhibiting and binary joint effects of 12 antibacterial agents on the freshwater green alga Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata (Korschikov) Hindak were investigated over 72-hr exposures. The toxicity values (the median inhibitory concentration value, in micromoles) in decreasing order of sensitivity were triclosan (0.0018) > triclocarban (0.054) > roxithromycin (0.056) > clarithromycin (0.062) > tylosin (0.20) > tetracycline (2.25) > chlortetracycline (3.49) > norfloxacin (5.64) > sulfamethoxazole (7.50) > ciprofloxacin (20.22) > sulfamethazine (31.26) > trimethoprim (137.78). Several of these antibacterial compounds would be toxic at the micrograms per liter concentrations reported in surface waters and sewage effluents. Simple additive effects were observed in binary mixtures of sulfonamides, and most tylosin, triclosan, or triclocarban combinations. Potentially synergistic effects were observed in binary mixtures of the same class, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, and fluoroquinolones, as well as in some combined drugs, such as trimethoprim and sulfonamides or tylosin and tetracyclines. Potentially antagonistic effects were only observed between tylosin and triclocarban, triclosan and norfloxacin, and triclocarban and norfloxacin. Although present at low concentrations in the aquatic environment, mixtures of these antibacterial agents can potentially affect algal growth in freshwater systems due to their combined action.

input: Could you specify the Ecotoxicity of the compound with the name (1R,7S)-4-(2-ethylhexyl)-4-azatricyclo[5.2.1.02,6]dec-8-ene-3,5-dione?
output: The molecule MGK 264 was tested in a 21-day short-term reproduction assay with fathead minnows (Pimephales promelas) in continuous flow-through conditions. Adult fish, 16 spawning groups (2 males and 4 females in each group; 4 groups/treatment; 4.5-6 months old) were exposed to MGK 264 (95.4% purity) at nominal concentrations of 0 (control), 0.011, 0.033, and 0.100 mg a.i./L; time-weighted average (TWA) concentrations were <LOQ (<0.001), 0.013, 0.036, and 0.107 mg a.i./L. The test system was maintained at 24.5 to 25.5 °C and a pH of 7.1 to 7.8. Adult male and female survival were unaffected by treatment with MGK 264; overall survival was 100% at all treatment levels. There were no notable observations with regards to behavior or changes in appearance, specifically color/banding, ovipositor appearance, or size of dorsal nape pad in the control or treated groups or clinical signs of toxicity for any treatment group compared to the controls. Body weights and lengths in MGK 264-treated fish were similar to the control. Spawning occurred at least two times in 7 days and fecundity in the negative control was 32.4 eggs/female/day/replicate (30.1-36.2); fertilization success in the negative control group averaged 99.1% (99.0-99.2%). Male gonado-somatic index (GSI) was the only endpoint to exhibit a treatment-related effect; there was a significant 45% increase in male GSI at the high treatment level, relative to the control (p<0.05; Dunnett's test). There were no statistically significant differences (p>0.05) in treated groups compared to negative control for any other endpoint (i.e., female GSI, and male and female vitellogenin and nuptial tubercle score). Histopathology showed no treatment-related effects in males or females at any treatment level. However, it should be noted that female fish (including controls) had findings of oocyte atresia (5-14%) sometimes associated with inflammation (5-11%) and presence of protozoal spores. Male fish (including controls) had findings of increased proportion of spermatogonia (13-63%), and increases in testicular degeneration (38-63%) sometimes associated with inflammation (13%) or interstitial cell (Leydig) hypertrophy/hyperplasia (25%) or a testis-ova (13%) or duct mineralization (25%). There were no statistically significant differences between gonadal stages in treated groups compared to the negative controls.

output: The molecule neonicotinoids, developed in the 1990s as an insecticide with selective toxicity, were later found to cause reproductive abnormalities in experimental animals. In Japan, there is an attempt to preserve endangered animals, including the Japanese crested ibis, and there is a question of whether neonicotinoids affect the reproduction of this bird, since they are used in its habitat. Whether the daily oral administration of the neonicotinoid clothianidin (CTD) has any deleterious effects on the reproductive function of mature male only or both young male and female quails as experimental animals was investigated. Vacuolization and the number of germ cells having fragmented DNA in seminiferous tubules, as well as the number and size of vacuoles in hepatocytes, increased dose-dependently. The ovaries showed abnormal histology in the granulosa cells, which produce progesterone. There were significant differences in egg-laying rates and embryo weights between the groups. Glutathione Peroxidase 4 (GPx4) and Manganese Superoxide Dismutase (Mn-SOD), which protect the organism from oxidative damage, showed a dose-dependent decrease. Thus, it is possible neonicotinoids affect the bird's reproductive system through oxidative stress, reflecting an imbalance between the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and a biological system's ability to readily detoxify the reactive intermediates or easily repair the resulting damage.

input: Can you share the Environmental Bioconcentration of the molecule known as tributyl(chloro)stannane?
output: The molecule BCFs in crucian carp (Carassius carassius grandoculis) obtained in a 7-day experiment were 589 (muscle), 457 (vertebra), 5012 (liver), and 3162 (kidney). BCFs for tributyltin in oysters ranged from 1000 (water concn 0.15 ug/l) and 5000 (water concn 1.25 ug/l). In studies in which the bioaccumulation and elimination of tributyltin in Red Sea bream (Pagrus major) was by direct uptake from water, from diet, and from both simultaneously, about a quarter of the bioaccumulation was due to dietary uptake. The accumulation factor for dietary uptake was 0.26-0.38 on a dry wt basis. The elimination rate was 0.031-0.037/day and was independent of the source of uptake, water or diet. Bioaccumulation was also independent of the form of tributyltin in the diet. Marine mussels (Mytilus graynus) collected in a lightly contaminated area and transplanted to a highly contaminated area had a BCF of 10,500 for tributyltin; the half-life was 4.68 days. Blue mussels (Mytilus edulis) collected from a highly contaminated area and transplanted to a lightly contaminated area had a BCF of 10,400 for tributyltin; the half-life was 4.82 days. Oligochaetes accumulate sediment-associated tributyltin, thus making it available to bottom feeding fish. According to a classification scheme, BCF values of >6,000 suggest bioconcentration of tributylchlorostannane (as tributyltin) in aquatic organisms is very high.

input: What is the value of the Environmental Biodegradation for the molecule N-[methoxy(methylsulfanyl)phosphoryl]acetamide?
output: The molecule is acephate. River die-away studies determined that acephate degraded more rapidly in non-sterile creek water as compared to sterilized creek water; after 50 days of incubation, 54.8% of initial acephate was degraded in non-sterile water while only 23.6% had degraded in sterile water; in water plus sediment tests, 74.5% degraded in non-sterile media while only 45% degraded in sterile media. Acephate degraded in aerobic soils with half-lives of generally < 3 days. Acephate, applied at concentrations of 1 or 10 ppm was rapidly degraded from a wide variety of soils (eight soils - 3 clays, loam, loamy sand, sandy clay loam, silty clay loam, muck) when incubated at 24 °C at field capacity open to the air (volatiles not trapped and degradates other than methamidophos were not identified). In all cases, half-lives in mineral soils were <3 days at 10 ppm and about 1.5 days at 1 ppm. Half-lives in an Ocoee muck soil (pH 5.3, 68% organic matter) were 6 days at 1 ppm and 13 days at 10 ppm. Average maximum concentrations of methamidophos were approximately 10% of the initially applied radioactivity. In sterile controls (Norwalk silty clay loam and Greenville clay), after 4 days, approximately 90-100% of the applied amount remained as acephate, compared to approximately 20 % in the non-sterile. The effect of varying moisture contents (5 and 15%) was tested with the Hanford loamy sand treated with 20 ppm acephate; volatiles were not trapped. Degradation was more rapid at 15% moisture content than at 5%. Acephate degraded with a first-order half-life of 6.6 days in anaerobic flooded clay sediment. The initial pH of the system was 7.0, increasing to pH 7.9 by the final sampling interval (day 20). Acephate, applied as a wettable powder at 0.75 lbs/A, dissipated with an observed half-life of 1-3 days in the upper 5 cm of a field plot of silt loam soil used for growing tobacco in Greenville, Mississippi, after six foliar applications (6- to 9-day intervals).

input: For the molecule named tert-butylbenzene, could you provide its Environmental Biodegradation?
output: The molecule is t-Butylbenzene reached 0.3% of its theoretical BOD using an acclimated activated sludge inoculum and the 5-day BOD test at 20 °C. Theoretical BODs ranging from 0.6% to 39.8% were measured using the Warburg test. Alkylbenzenes are known to be oxidized by microorganisms. t-Butylbenzene was degraded using Moustorod Refinery wastewater inoculum, exhibiting 14, 100, and 100 % degradation in 7, 15, and 23 days, respectively; similar results were observed in non-aerated tests. t-Butylbenzene at a concn of 19-25 ppm was 10 and 30% removed after 20 and 80 days, respectively, in a grab sample study using water from the Ohio River, although volatilization could not be ruled out. Biological loss of t-butylbenzene was noted using artificial seawater acclimated with 100 ml gas oil at 20 °C for 3 days and then inoculated with North Sea coast water although the sample compound could not be resolved from 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene. t-Butylbenzene at a concn of 100 mg/l in an automated continuous respirometer study resulted in a growth rate of 1.21 1/day using an activated sludge inoculum following a lag of 4.40 days.

input: I'm interested in knowing the Environmental Biodegradation of WAPNOHKVXSQRPX-UHFFFAOYSA-N. Could you provide that?
output: The molecule is rapidly biodegraded in an aerobic, sewage die-away screening test with 78.2% of the theoretical BOD reached in 8-10 days. Phenol-adapted cultures grown without the molecule, with the molecule (at 100 mg/L), and with both phenol and the molecule consumed 69, 75, and 320 ul O2, respectively, over a 210 minute period. An Arthrobacter strain initially dehydrogenates the molecule to acetophenone which is then converted to an ester, producing phenyl acetate which is then hydrolysed to phenol and acetate. A Nocardia strain first oxygenates the benzene nucleus to give 3-(1'-hydroxyethyl)-3,5-cyclo-hexadiene-1,2-diol which is then reduced and subjected to extra-diol cleavage. This same strain is also able to degrade the molecule using the same pathway as described above for Arthrobacter. The molecule, inoculated with a mixed microbial culture, was readily biodegraded from 550 ppm to 20 ppm over 32 days. Nitrosomonas europaea degraded 2.5% of the molecule (initially present at 200 nmol) over a 15 hour period. The molecule had a BOD of 1.0 g/g after a 10 day incubation with a sewage inoculum.

input: I would like to know the Evidence for Carcinogenicity of the molecule referred to as O=[Cr](=O)([O-])[O-].[NH4+].[NH4+].
output: The molecule is classified as a known human carcinogen by the inhalation route of exposure. Carcinogenicity by the oral route of exposure cannot be determined and is classified as Group D. The molecule would be characterized as a known human carcinogen by the inhalation route of exposure on the following basis. The molecule is known to be carcinogenic in humans by the inhalation route of exposure. Results of occupational epidemiological studies of workers exposed to the molecule are consistent across investigators and study populations. Dose-response relationships have been established for exposure to the molecule and lung cancer. Workers exposed to the molecule are exposed to both trivalent and hexavalent compounds. Because only hexavalent compounds have been found to be carcinogenic in animal studies, it was concluded that only hexavalent compounds should be classified as human carcinogens. Animal data are consistent with the human carcinogenicity data on the molecule. Hexavalent compounds are carcinogenic in animal bioassays, producing various tumor types. In vitro data are suggestive of a potential mode of action for carcinogenesis. Carcinogenesis may result from the formation of mutagenic oxidatitive DNA lesions following intracellular reduction to the trivalent form. The molecule readily passes through cell membranes and is rapidly reduced intracellularly to generate reactive intermediates and reactive oxygen species. A number of potentially mutagenic DNA lesions are formed during the reduction of the molecule. The molecule is mutagenic in bacterial assays, yeasts and cells, and compounds decrease the fidelity of DNA synthesis in vitro and produce unscheduled DNA synthesis as a consequence of DNA damage. input: I'm interested in knowing the Food Survey Values of CFMYXEVWODSLAX-PVLZPDSLSA-N. Could you provide that?
output: The molecule is a toxin found in puffer fish, also known as puffer, fugu, bok, blowfish, globefish, swellfish, balloonfish, or sea squab. It is heavily restricted for commercial importation into the United States due to potential health hazards. The liver, gonads (ovaries and testes), intestines, and skin of puffer fish typically contain the toxin. The toxin cannot be destroyed by cooking or freezing, and freezing and thawing of the product prior to removal of the toxic organs may result in the migration of toxin into the flesh of the fish. The State of Florida currently has a ban on both commercial and recreational harvesting of puffer fish from certain counties due to persistent toxicity. Puffer fish harvested from these Florida counties have been found to contain significant amounts of toxin in the flesh regardless of the preparation technique. The Northern Puffer fish from the mid-Atlantic coastal waters of the United States, typically between Virginia and New York, has not been found to contain toxin, but without routine toxin screening there still is a potential risk.

input: Tell me the Hazard Effects of the molecule LELOWRISYMNNSU-UHFFFAOYSA-N, please.
output: The molecule is capable of releasing cyanide when burned under certain conditions, posing risks during electroplating and waste disposal. Notably, some individuals lack the ability to detect cyanide odor. Mixing water-soluble cyanide salts with water can generate hazardous quantities of hydrogen cyanide (HCN), with potential risks even from showering in contaminated clothing. Skin exposure to solid cyanide salts or their solutions can lead to lethal cyanide absorption. Inhalation of 600 to 700 ppm HCN for 5 minutes or 200 ppm for 30 minutes may be fatal. In smoke inhalation cases, cyanide-induced hypoxia mirrors that of carbon monoxide. Chemicals such as acetone cyanohydrin, potassium cyanide, and sodium cyanide can release significant amounts of HCN when spilled in water. See CYANIDES for further information.

input: For the molecule identified as CS(=O)(=O)F, what is its Hazard Effects?

In rats chronically exposed in utero, sex-specific changes in brain development were observed. It reacts with water, producing hydrogen fluoride gas. Additionally, it is corrosive and highly toxic when inhaled. High-dose animal studies have shown effects including inhibition of true cholinesterase and degenerative changes in the brain.

input: What is the Health Effects associated with the molecule InChI=1S/C10H12N2O/c1-12-9(4-5-10(12)13)8-3-2-6-11-7-8/h2-3,6-7,9H,4-5H2,1H3?
output: The molecule binds to, activates, and desensitizes neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, though at much lower potency in comparison to nicotine. input: Can you share the Health Effects of the molecule known as toluene?
output: The molecule can cause a cholinergic crisis characterized by severe nausea/vomiting, salivation, sweating, bradycardia, hypotension, collapse, and convulsions. Increasing muscle weakness is a possibility and may result in death if respiratory muscles are involved. Accumulation of ACh at motor nerves causes overstimulation of nicotinic expression at the neuromuscular junction. When this occurs symptoms such as muscle weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps, fasciculation, and paralysis can be seen. When there is an accumulation of ACh at autonomic ganglia this causes overstimulation of nicotinic expression in the sympathetic system. Symptoms associated with this are hypertension, and hypoglycemia. Overstimulation of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system, due to accumulation of ACh, results in anxiety, headache, convulsions, ataxia, depression of respiration and circulation, tremor, general weakness, and potentially coma. When there is expression of muscarinic overstimulation due to excess acetylcholine at muscarinic acetylcholine receptors symptoms of visual disturbances, tightness in chest, wheezing due to bronchoconstriction, increased bronchial secretions, increased salivation, lacrimation, sweating, peristalsis, and urination can occur. Certain reproductive effects in fertility, growth, and development for males and females have been linked specifically to organophosphate pesticide exposure. Most of the research on reproductive effects has been conducted on farmers working with pesticides and insecticides in rural areas. In females menstrual cycle disturbances, longer pregnancies, spontaneous abortions, stillbirths, and some developmental effects in offspring have been linked to organophosphate pesticide exposure. Prenatal exposure has been linked to impaired fetal growth and development. Neurotoxic effects have also been linked to poisoning with OP pesticides causing four neurotoxic effects in humans: cholinergic syndrome, intermediate syndrome, organophosphate-induced delayed polyneuropathy (OPIDP), and chronic organophosphate-induced neuropsychiatric disorder (COPIND). These syndromes result after acute and chronic exposure to OP pesticides.

input: Can you indicate the Health Effects for the molecule 2-bromo-2-nitropropane-1,3-diol?
output: The molecule may react to produce nitrosamines which are believed to be carcinogenic it also releases formaldehyde a known human carcinogen.

The molecule causes cardiovascular symptoms such as angina pectoris, AV block (2nd & 3rd degree), atrioventricular dissociation, CHF, pulmonary edema, chest pain, claudication, myocardial infarction, palpitations, purpura (vasculitis), and syncope.

The molecule leads to digestive system issues including diarrhea, dry mouth, gastrointestinal distress, and gingival hyperplasia.

The molecule affects the hemic and lymphatic systems, resulting in ecchymosis or bruising.

The molecule impacts the nervous system, causing cerebrovascular accident, confusion, equilibrium disorders, insomnia, muscle cramps, psychotic symptoms, shakiness, somnolence, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

The molecule can cause skin problems such as arthralgia and rash, exanthema, hair loss, hyperkeratosis, macules, sweating, urticaria, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and erythema multiforme.

The molecule may lead to special senses issues like blurred vision and tinnitus.

The molecule can result in urogenital symptoms including gynecomastia, galactorrhea/hyperprolactinemia, increased urination, spotty menstruation, and impotence.

input: Tell me the Health Effects of the molecule OUULRIDHGPHMNQ-UHFFFAOYSA-N, please.
output: The molecule can cause dermal exposure to result in antimony spots, such as papules and pustules around sweat and sebaceous glands. Antimony poisoning can also lead to pneumoconiosis. input: Tell me the Health Effects of the molecule CN(C)C(=O)OC1=CC(=O)CC(C)(C)C1, please.
output: The molecule causes acute exposure to cholinesterase inhibitors to result in a cholinergic crisis characterized by severe nausea/vomiting, salivation, sweating, bradycardia, hypotension, collapse, and convulsions. Increasing muscle weakness is a possibility and may result in death if respiratory muscles are involved. Accumulation of ACh at motor nerves causes overstimulation of nicotinic expression at the neuromuscular junction, leading to symptoms such as muscle weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps, fasciculation, and paralysis. Accumulation of ACh at autonomic ganglia causes overstimulation of nicotinic expression in the sympathetic system, resulting in symptoms such as hypertension and hypoglycemia. Overstimulation of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system, due to accumulation of ACh, results in anxiety, headache, convulsions, ataxia, depression of respiration and circulation, tremor, general weakness, and potentially coma. Expression of muscarinic overstimulation due to excess acetylcholine at muscarinic acetylcholine receptors leads to symptoms of visual disturbances, tightness in chest, wheezing due to bronchoconstriction, increased bronchial secretions, increased salivation, lacrimation, sweating, peristalsis, and urination. Chronically high (>10 years) exposure leads to neuropsychological consequences including disturbances in perception and visuo-motor processing.

input: What is the value of the Health Effects for the molecule sulfanylideneantimony?
output: The molecule can cause dermal exposure to result in antimony spots, such as papules and pustules around sweat and sebaceous glands. Antimony poisoning can also lead to pneumoconiosis. Inhalation of the molecule can result in alterations in pulmonary function and other effects, including chronic bronchitis, chronic emphysema, inactive tuberculosis, pleural adhesions, and irritation. Additionally, increased blood pressure can result from antimony poisoning. Myocardial depression, vasodilation, and fluid loss may cause shock with hypotension, electrolyte disturbances, and acute renal failure. Cerebral oedema, coma, convulsions, and death are possible outcomes.

input: Can you provide the Health Effects for the substance named InChI=1S/C2H7AsO2.Na/c1-3(2,4)5;/h1-2H3,(H,4,5);/q;+1?
output: The molecule causes hypovolemia from capillary leakage (third-spacing of fluids) as a common, serious, early effect. Muscle cramps, facial edema, bronchitis, dyspnea, chest pain, dehydration, intense thirst, and fluid-electrolyte disturbances are also common following significant exposures. A garlic-like odor of the breath and feces may also occur. After absorption, the molecule may cause multi-organ failure by inhibiting sulfhydryl-containing enzymes. Encephalopathy, with headache, lethargy, mental confusion, hallucinations, emotional lability, memory loss and delirium may occur; seizures, stupor, convulsions, coma, and death may follow within 24 hours of a severe acute exposure. Dysrhythmias (particularly QTc prolongation and torsade de pointes), cardiomyopathy, ARDS, hepatitis, rhabdomyolysis, hemolysis, and renal failure may develop over several days. The sequence of chronic poisoning involves hyperpigmentation, and eczematoid and allergic dermatitis. Muscle fasciculations; gross tremors; ataxia; incoordination; and mental confusion. Muscular weakness, limb tenderness and difficulty walking may follow. The final phase consists of peripheral sensory neuropathy of the hands and feet. That may be associated with a motor neuropathy as well.

For the HFC 134a study, the t(1/2)alpha (alpha elimination half-life) was short for both CFC 12 and HFC 134a (<11 min). The t(1/2)beta (beta elimination half-life) across all exposure concentrations was a mean of 36 and 42 min for CFC 12 and HFC 134a, respectively. Mean residence time (MRT) was an overall mean of 42 and 44 min for CFC 12 and HFC 134a, respectively. In the HFC 227 study, t(1/2)alpha for both CFC 12 and HFC 227, at each exposure level, was short (<9 min) and tended to be lower in males than females. For CFC 12 mean t(1/2)beta ranged from 23 to 43 min and for HFC 227 the mean range was 19-92 min. The values tended to be lower for females than males for HFC 227. For both CFC 12 and HFC 227, MRT was statistically significantly lower (P < 0.05) in males than females and independent of exposure concentration. For CFC 12, MRT was a mean of 37 and 45 min for males and females, respectively, and for HFC 227 MRT was a mean of 36 and 42 min, respectively. Exposure of healthy volunteers to exposure levels up to 8000 ppm HFC 134a, 8000 ppm HFC 227, and 4000 ppm CFC 12 did not result in any adverse effects on pulse, blood pressure, electrocardiogram, or lung function.

input: For the molecule named ethene, could you provide its Medical Surveillance?
output: The molecule hemoglobin adducts were analyzed as a biomonitoring tool following a chemical plant fire near Cologne, Germany in 2008. Over 1000 individuals potentially encountered acrylonitrile and ethylene. Air monitoring revealed acrylonitrile concentrations up to 20 ppm, with a mean of 7 ppm over 8 hours. Biomonitoring was advised for those involved, and 816 individuals underwent blood sampling. Hemoglobin adducts of acrylonitrile (N-(2-cyanoethyl) valine) and ethylene (N-(2-hydroxyethyl) valine) were analyzed due to erythrocyte lifespan. Most adduct levels were below internal reference values (CyEtVal<15 ug/L blood or <612 pmol/g globin; HyEtVal<15 ug/L blood or 646 pmol/g globin), with only 1% slightly exceeding them. Biomonitoring results indicated lower body burdens than anticipated from air data, emphasizing the importance of biomonitoring alongside air monitoring after chemical incidents.

input: Please tell me the Medical Surveillance of the compound named PWYIUEFFPNVCMW-UHFFFAOYSA-N.
output: The molecule measurement of whole blood-AChE is the most widely adopted method for monitoring the effects of occupational exposure to organophosphorus insecticides. Physiological variations in blood ChE levels occur in a healthy person and are seen among a population. It has been estimated that the coefficient of variation for AChE activity in samples from an individual is 8-11%, and that a decrease of 23% below pre-exposure level may, therefore, be considered significant. If the average of several pre-exposure values were available, then a decrease of 17% would be significant. It has been recommended that, if measured activity is reduced by 30% or more of the pre-exposure value, AChE measurements should be repeated at appropriate intervals to confirm the results. Depressions of AChE or ChE in excess of 20-25% are considered diagnostic of exposure but not, necessarily, indicative of hazard. Depressions of 30-50% or more are considered indicators for removal of an exposed individual from further contact with pesticides until levels return to normal.

output: The molecule's optimum routine bioassay sampling frequency for tritium is once every 2 weeks (biweekly) for periodic acute intakes of tritium. Where exposure conditions are well established and anticipated tritium doses are low (e.g., less than 100 mrem for the year), less frequent intervals (e.g., monthly to quarterly) are adequate. However, the uncertainties with dose estimates associated with longer sampling intervals become much higher. Because of the 10-day effective half-life and the uncertainties associated with a possible organically bound tritium component, sampling intervals for HTO greater than 90 days are specifically not recommended. input: For the molecule named (2S)-2,6-diaminohexanoic acid, could you provide its Milk Concentrations?
output: The molecule is an indicator of protein quality and nutritional value of milk. Many studies have examined the effects of extraction, treatment and storage of human milk upon its components, though no references are found regarding the possible changes in milk quality as defined by its content in essential amino acids such as lysine. The present study investigates the available lysine content in human milk and the variations in lysine resulting from milk manipulation as follows: (a) Cold storage (refrigeration at 4 °C for 48 hours, and frozen for 15 days at -20 °C); (b) Thermal treatment under conditions of low (Holder)(63 °C/30 minutes) and high pasteurization (75 °C/15 seconds). The results obtained show a decrease in milk lysine concentration after storage in both refrigerated and frozen samples. Pasteurization causes a highly significant loss of available lysine. The lysine losses were greater on applying low pasteurization versus the more gentle conditions of high pasteurization. Conclusions: While manipulation through cold storage or thermal treatment does not affect the protein content of human milk, its protein quality is modified. When human milk must be subjected to hygienization, it is preferable to apply high temperature treatment (75 °C, 15 seconds) than habitual pasteurization (63 °C, 30 minutes).

output: The molecule is a threonine content of most of the infant formulas currently on the market is approximately 20% higher than the threonine concentration in human milk. Due to this high threonine content the plasma threonine concentrations are up to twice as high in premature infants fed these formulas than in infants fed human milk. To study the effect of different threonine intakes on plasma and tissue amino acid concentrations, 24 young male Wistar rats were fed three experimental diets based on a mixture of bovine proteins with a whey protein/casein ratio of 60/40 with different threonine contents [group A, 0.86 g of threonine/100 g (n = 8); group B, 1.03 g of threonine/100 g (n = 8); group C, 2.21 g of threonine/100 g (n = 8)]. Eight animals were fed a typical rat diet based on bovine casein as controls. After a feeding period of 15 d, amino acids were measured in plasma and in homogenates of the cerebral cortex, brain stem, liver, and muscle. There was a significant correlation between threonine intake and plasma threonine levels (r = 0.687, p < 0.001). The plasma threonine concentration correlated significantly with the threonine concentration in the cortex (r = 0.821, p < 0.01) and the brain stem (r = 0.882, p < 0.01). There was a positive significant correlation between threonine and glycine concentrations in the cortex (r = 0.673, p < 0.01), and the brain stem (r = 0.575, p < 0.01), whereas the glycine concentration decreased with increasing threonine intakes in the liver and muscle. The presented data indicate that increasing the threonine in plasma leads to increasing brain glycine and thereby affects the neurotransmitter balance in the brain. This may have consequences for brain development during early postnatal life. Therefore, excessive threonine intake during infant feeding should be avoided.

The study characterized infant drug doses and breast-milk-to-plasma area-under-the-curve ratios for olanzapine and determined plasma concentrations and effects of this drug on breast-feeding infants. Seven mother-infant nursing pairs were studied. Olanzapine was measured in plasma and milk with high-performance liquid chromatography over a dose interval (for six patients) or at a single time after dose ingestion (for one patient) at steady state. Infant drug exposure was estimated as the product of an assumed milk production rate and average drug concentration in milk, normalized to body weight, and expressed as a percentage of maternal drug dose, normalized to body weight. The median infant dose of olanzapine ingested through milk was 1.02% of the maternal dose; the median milk-to-plasma area-under-the-curve ratio was 0.38 for the six patients with data collected over the dose interval. Corresponding values in the patient with single-point data were 1.13% and 0.75. Olanzapine was not detected in the plasma of the six infants with an evaluable plasma sample. All of the infants were healthy and experienced no side effects. Breast-fed infants were exposed to a calculated olanzapine dose of approximately 1% - well below the 10% notional level of concern. In infant plasma, olanzapine was below the detection limit; there were no adverse effects on the infants. These data support the use of olanzapine during breast-feeding. However, the authors recommend that breast-fed infants be monitored closely and the decision to breast-feed be made after individual risk-benefit analysis.

input: Could you specify the National Toxicology Program Studies of the compound with the name 2-aminobenzoic acid?
output: The molecule was administered to Fischer 344 and B6C3F1 mice at doses of either 15,000 or 30,000 ppm for rats and either 25,000 or 50,000 ppm for mice, 5 days/wk for 78 wk, then observed for an additional 26-27 wk. Matched controls consisted of groups of 15 rats and 15 mice of each sex; pooled controls, used for statistical evaluation, consisted of the matched controls combined with 15 untreated male and 15 untreated female animals of each species from a similar bioassay of another test chemical. Except for the matched control male mice, all surviving animals in the study were killed at 104-106 wk. Half of the matched control male mice, which were accidentally killed at week 12, were excluded from the report; the remaining matched control males died by week 94. Mean body weights of the low- and high-dose male and high-dose female rats were lower than those of the corresponding matched controls for the duration of the study. The weights of the low-dose females were similar to those of the matched controls for the first 45 weeks, after which they declined slightly. The weights of the low-dose male mice were similar to those of the matched controls, while those of the high-dose males and of the low- and high-dose females were slightly lower. Survival of both treated and matched-control groups of rats of both sexes was high; survival of treated mice of both sexes and of female matched controls, although lower than that of the rats, was sufficient for meaningful statistical analyses of the incidences of tumors. In rats, a variety of neoplasms were observed in both treated and control animals. Few malignant tumors were found, and no tumors occurred in treated animals in statistically significant incidences when compared with control animals. In mice, a variety of neoplasms were observed in both treated and control animals. These neoplasms are not uncommon in this strain of mouse, and none occurred in treated animals in statistically significant incidences when compared with control animals. It is concluded that under the conditions of this bioassay, the molecule was not carcinogenic for either Fischer 344 rats or B6C3F1 mice.

input: Could you specify the National Toxicology Program Studies of the compound with the name chromen-2-one?
output: The molecule coumarin (97% pure) was administered in corn oil by gavage to groups of male and female F344/N rats and B6C3F1 mice for 2 years. In the 2-year study in rats, groups of 60 male and 60 female rats were administered coumarin in corn oil by gavage at doses of 0, 25, 50, or 100 mg/kg body weight. In the 2-year study in mice, groups of 70 male and 70 female mice were administered coumarin in corn oil by gavage at doses of 0, 50, 100, or 200 mg/kg body weight for up to 2 years. Under the conditions of these 2-year gavage studies, there was some evidence of carcinogenic activity of coumarin in male F344/N rats based on increased incidences of renal tubule adenomas. There was equivocal evidence of carcinogenic activity of coumarin in female F344/N rats based on a marginally increased incidence of renal tubule adenomas. There was some evidence of carcinogenic activity of coumarin in male B6C3F1 mice based on the increased incidence of alveolar/bronchiolar adenomas. There was clear evidence of carcinogenic activity of coumarin in female B6C3F1 mice based on increased incidences of alveolar/bronchiolar adenomas, alveolar/bronchiolar carcinomas, and hepatocellular adenomas. The marginally increased incidences of squamous cell papillomas of the forestomach in male and female mice receiving 50 mg/kg may have been related to coumarin administration.

input: Can you provide the National Toxicology Program Studies for the substance named QWVGKYWNOKOFNN-UHFFFAOYSA-N?
output: The molecule was evaluated for reproductive toxicity in CD-1 (Swiss) mice using the Reproductive Assessment by Continuous Breeding Protocol (RACB). Exposure to the molecule at levels ranging from a mean of 66 mg/kg/day in the low-dose group (0.05% in feed) to a mean of 660 mg/kg/day in the high-dose group (0.05% in feed) for 14 wks of cohabitation did not significantly affect measures of reproductive competence, including initial fertility, mean number of litters/pair, live litter size, the proportion of pups born alive, or adjusted live pup weight. A small but significant non-dose-related increase (2-3 days) in cumulative days to litter was observed in the three treated groups. F0 body weight, feed, and water consumption, after 16 weeks of exposure, were not adversely affected by treatment. Treatment had no effect on body or liver, kidney, or testis weight at necropsy, with the exception of a decrease in absolute but not relative kidney weight among females in the high-dose group. No treatment-related testicular histopathology was observed. The molecule at a dose level of 0.5% in feed did not adversely affect preweaning growth or survival in the F1 generation, nor was there an effect of this dose level on feed or water consumption in the F1 generation. Calculated exposure averaged 773 and 1128 mg/kg/day for adult F1 males and females, respectively. No treatment-related clinical signs were noted. The molecule at 0.5% in feed had no effect on the reproductive competence of the F1 generation. There was no effect of treatment on male body weight or liver, epididymis, kidney, prostate, seminal vesicle, or testis weight, sperm parameters, or histopathology. Female terminal body weight was slightly reduced, but there was no effect on organ weight, vaginal cytology, or liver, kidney, or ovarian histopathology. In summary, exposure to the molecule in feed at dose levels as high as 0.5% had no significant adverse effect on reproductive competence in F0 or F1 mice. However, the max tolerated dose (MTD) was not reached, because no evidence of generalized toxicity was noted for the F0 generation at 0.5% of the molecule, and only minimal evidence of generalized toxicity was noted for F1 females at 0.5% of the molecule. Although the MTD was not reached for the F0 generation, data from Task 1 suggested that the animals could not have tolerated higher doses for the length of exposures in Tasks 2 and 3. The 0.2% dose level was the no adverse effects level (NOAEL) for both reproductive and general toxicity in both generations. These data indicate that the molecule is not a reproductive toxicant to either F0 or F1 mice under the conditions of this study (i.e., up to 1230 mg/kg/day).

input: Please tell me the National Toxicology Program Studies of the compound named RLSSMJSEOOYNOY-UHFFFAOYSA-N.
output: The molecule was evaluated for reproductive toxicity in CD-1 (Swiss) mice using the Reproductive Assessment by Continuous Breeding (RACB) Protocol. Exposure to the molecule, at levels ranging from a mean of 362 mg/kg/day in the low-dose group (0.25% in feed) to a mean of 1682 mg/kg/day in the high-dose group (1.5% in feed), for 14 wks of cohabitation, did not significantly affect most measures of reproductive competence, including initial fertility, the proportion of pups born alive, or the sex of pups born alive. However, adjusted the pup weight & the number of live pups/litter (both sexes) were decreased by 5 & 20%, respectively, & cumulative days to the fifth litter were increased by almost 3 days in the high-dose group compared to controls. F0 body weight & feed consumption, after 16 wks of exposure, were decreased at the 1.0 & 1.5% dose levels, especially in delivering & lactating dams. At the 1.5% level decreased body weight & increased kidney & liver weights of F0 animals. Toxicity to reproductive organs at the 1.5% dose level was observed in the form of decreased epididymal & seminal vesicle weights by 10 & 21%, respectively, with no change in testis weight, sperm parameters, or testicular & epididymal histopathology. Crossover mating did not clearly reveal the affected sex as the only parameter affected (adjusted live pup weight) was decreased if either sex was dosed at the 1.5% level. Although birth weights of F1 animals were minimally decreased (5.0%) in the high-dose group, the molecule decreased preweaning growth by 26% & postweaning survival by 39% in the F1 generation. Calculated exposure in high-dose F1 animals averaged 2490 mg/kg/day for males & 2939 mg/kg/day for females. Treatment-related clinical signs were reduced size, dehydration, lethargy, & rough coat in the high-dose group. The molecule at 1.5% in feed had no effect on the reproductive competence of the F1 generation. At both the 1.0 & 1.5% dose level, male body & reproductive organ weights (prostate, seminal vesicles, testes) were decreased & relative liver & kidney weights were increased, but there were no effects on sperm parameters or histopathology. Female terminal body weights were reduced at the two highest dose levels, as was ovarian weight in all three dosed groups, while kidney & liver weights were increased in all dosed groups. There was no effect of treatment on estrous cyclicity or ovarian, liver, or kidney histopathology. An MTD for systemic & reproductive toxicity of the molecule for F0 animals was established at the 1.5% dose level, based on decreased body weight at necropsy, increased relative liver weight, & decreased absolute & relative seminal vesicle weight. An MTD of 1.0% for systemic & reproductive toxicity was established for F1 animals, based on decreased body weight, increased relative liver weight, & decreased relative prostate & seminal vesicle weight. In summary, minimal reproductive toxicity was apparent, but only in the presence of significant systemic toxicity.

input: What is the National Toxicology Program Studies associated with the molecule 2,3,4,5,6-pentachlorophenol?
output: The molecule was tested in carcinogenicity bioassays using different concentrations fed to groups of male and female mice. In male mice, there was clear evidence of carcinogenic activity with increased incidences of adrenal medullary and hepatocellular neoplasms. In female mice, there was some evidence of carcinogenic activity with increased incidences of hemangiosarcomas and hepatocellular carcinomas. Additionally, male mice exposed to the molecule showed clear evidence of carcinogenic activity with increased incidences of adrenal medullary and hepatocellular neoplasms. Female mice exposed to the molecule also showed clear evidence of carcinogenic activity with increased incidences of adrenal medullary and hepatocellular neoplasms and hemangiosarcomas.

input: For the molecule identified as phenol, what is its National Toxicology Program Studies?
output: The molecule was tested for possible carcinogenicity by administering it in drinking water to F344 rats and B6C3F1 mice. Groups of 50 rats and 50 mice of each sex were given drinking water with 2,500 or 5,000 ppm of the molecule for 103 weeks. Matched control groups received tap water. Under these conditions, the molecule was not found to be carcinogenic for male or female F344 rats or male and female B6C3F1 mice. Levels of Evidence of Carcinogenicity: Male Rats: Negative; Female Rats: Negative; Male Mice: Negative; Female Mice: Negative.

input: I would like to know the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule referred to as 1-(4-acetylphenyl)sulfonyl-3-cyclohexylurea.
output: The molecule was administered to groups of 35 male and female Fischer 344 rats in diets containing 10,000 or 20,000 ppm for 103 weeks. Matched controls included 15 untreated rats of each sex. All surviving rats were euthanized between 105 and 107 weeks. The molecule was given to groups of 35 male and female mice in diets containing a time-weighted average of 6,359 or 12,718 ppm for 103 weeks. Matched controls included 15 untreated mice of each sex. input: For the molecule identified as 3-(2-chlorophenothiazin-10-yl)-N,N-dimethylpropan-1-amine, what is its National Toxicology Program Studies?
output: The molecule was administered in distilled water at various doses on gestational days 6 through 15. Females were monitored for signs of toxicity during treatment and at specific time points post-dosing. At sacrifice on gestational days 20, dams were evaluated. During treatment, dams showed signs of sedation, coat changes, weight loss, and lacrimation. Maternal mortality rates varied among dose groups. Maternal body weight did not differ significantly at the start of treatment, but decreased with higher doses. Maternal weight gain and gravid uterine weight were also reduced in a dose-dependent manner. Liver weight decreased with higher doses. The percentage of affected fetuses increased with dose, but malformations did not differ significantly. Overall, the molecule produced maternal and fetal toxicity, increased prenatal mortality, but did not increase malformations in rats.

input: I would like to know the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule referred to as ClC(Cl)=C(c1ccc(Cl)cc1)c1ccc(Cl)cc1.
output: The molecule DDT was administered in the feed to Osborne-Mendel rats and B6C3F1 mice at two different concentrations. The molecule TDE was also administered in the feed to these animals at varying concentrations. The molecule p,p'-DDE was administered in the feed to the animals as well. After the dosing period, there was an observation period. The results showed no evidence of carcinogenicity for DDT in rats or mice, TDE in female rats or mice of either sex, or p,p'-DDE in rats. However, p,p'-DDE was found to be hepatotoxic in rats. TDE showed a possible carcinogenic effect in male rats, specifically in the thyroid. p,p'-DDE was found to be carcinogenic in mice, causing hepatocellular carcinomas in both sexes. input: For the molecule named InChI=1S/C13H12F2N6O/c14-10-1-2-11(12(15)3-10)13(22,4-20-8-16-6-18-20)5-21-9-17-7-19-21/h1-3,6-9,22H,4-5H2, could you provide its National Toxicology Program Studies?
output: The molecule was tested on female B6C3F1 mice. The doses of the molecule ranged from 1.0% to 10% in 100% ethanol for sensitization and 10% for challenge. Mice received 20 ul by direct dermal application for 5 consecutive days to a prepared site. Site preparation included intradermal injection of Freund's complete adjuvant in some mice. DNFB was used as a positive control at a concentration of 0.25% for sensitization and 0.5% for challenge. Measurement of the contact hypersensitivity response was accomplished by the mouse ear swelling test (MEST). No statistically significant or dose-dependent contact hypersensitivity response to the molecule could be detected.

input: What is the National Toxicology Program Studies associated with the molecule InChI=1S/FH.Na/h1H;/q;+1/p-1?
output: The molecule received sodium fluoride in drinking water at concentrations as high as 800 ppm. In the high-dose groups, male and female rats and male mice died; one female rat was given 400 ppm in the drinking water also died before the end of the studies. No gross lesions were attributed to sodium fluoride administration. Rats received concentrations of sodium fluoride in drinking water as high as 300 ppm, and mice as high as 600 ppm. No rats died during the studies; however, among the mice, high-dose males, high-dose females, and males in the 300 ppm group died before the end of the studies. Weight gains were less than those of controls for rats receiving 300 ppm and mice receiving 200 to 600 ppm. The teeth of rats and mice receiving the higher doses of sodium fluoride were chalky white and chipped or showed unusual wear patterns. Mice and male rats given the higher concentrations had microscopic focal degeneration of the enamel organ. Rats receiving 100 or 300 ppm sodium fluoride had minimal hyperplasia of the gastric mucosa of the stomach, and one high-dose rat of each sex had an ulcer. Acute nephrosis and/or lesions in the liver and myocardium were observed in mice that died early, and minimal alterations in bone growth/remodeling were observed in the long bones of mice receiving sodium fluoride at concentrations of 50 to 600 ppm. The sodium fluoride concentrations selected for the 2-year studies in both rats and mice were 0, 25, 100, and 175 ppm in the drinking water. The teeth of rats and mice has a dose-dependent whitish discoloration, and male rats had an increased incidence of tooth deformities and attrition leading on occasion to malocclusion. The teeth of male and, to a lesser degree, female rats had areas of microscopic dentine dysplasia and degeneration of ameloblasts. Dentine dysplasia occurred in both dosed and control groups of male and female mice; the incidence of this lesion was significantly greater in high-dose than in control male mice. Osteosclerosis of long bones was increased in female rats given drinking water containing 175 ppm sodium fluoride. No other significant nonneoplastic lesions in rats or mice appeared related to sodium fluoride administration. Osteosarcomas of bone were observed in male rats in the 100 ppm group and in male rats in the 175 ppm group. None were seen in the control or 25 ppm dose groups. One other 175 ppm male rat had an extra skeletal osteosarcoma arising in the subcutaneous tissue. Osteosarcomas occur in historical control male rats at an incidence of 0.5%. The historical incidence is not directly comparable with the incidences observed in this study because examination of bone was more comprehensive in the sodium fluoride studies than in previous NTP studies of other chemicals, and the diet used in previous studies was not controlled for fluoride content. In the current study, although the pairwise comparison of the incidence in the 175 ppm group versus that in the controls was not statistically significant, osteosarcomas occurred with a statistically significant dose-response trend, leading to the conclusion that a weak association may exist between the occurrence of these neoplasms and the administration of sodium fluoride. No other neoplastic lesions in rats or mice were considered possibly related to chemical administration. Under the conditions of these 2-year dosed water studies, there was equivocal evidence of carcinogenic activity of sodium fluoride in male F344/N rats, based on the occurrence of a small number of osteosarcomas in dosed animals. "Equivocal evidence" is a category for uncertain findings defined as studies that are interpreted as showing a marginal increase of neoplasms that may be related to chemical administration. There was no evidence of carcinogenic activity in female F344/N rats receiving sodium fluoride at concentrations of 25, 100, or 175 ppm in drinking water for 2 years. There was no evidence of carcinogenic activity of sodium fluoride in male or female mice receiving sodium fluoride at concentrations of 25, 100, or 175 ppm in drinking water for 2 years. Dosed rats had lesions typical of fluorosis of the teeth and female rats receiving drinking water containing 175 ppm sodium fluoride had increased osteosclerosis of long bones.

input: What is the value of the National Toxicology Program Studies for the molecule 4-amino-N-(4,6-dimethylpyrimidin-2-yl)benzenesulfonamide?
output: The molecule was tested for its effects on reproduction and fertility in CD-1 mice using the RACB protocol. Data from a 2 week dose-range-finding study (Task 1) were used to set exposure concentrations for the Task 2 continuous cohabitation study at 0.25, 0.50, and 1.0%. These concentrations produced average estimated daily intakes of nearly 425, 805, and 1,450 mg/kg/day. In the F0 generation, 2 low dose mice died during Task 2, and 1 middle dose group mouse died; these deaths were not attributed to molecule consumption by the study pathologist. Body weights and food consumption were not different across groups during Task 2. During Task 2, the high dose group delivered nearly 20% fewer litters, and those litters contained nearly 6 live pups, compared to 11 pups in control litters. Adjusted live pup weight was reduced by nearly 10%. Additionally, with the exception of the third litter, all treated groups took 1-8 days longer than the controls to deliver each litter. The effect was greatest at the high dose. These reproductive effects prompted the conduct of Task 3 to determine the affected sex, using control and high dose mice. Approximately 70% of pairs mated and delivered live pups in all groups in Task 3. The groups containing a treated partner delivered nearly 34-40% fewer pups per litter compared to controls; adjusted pup weight was not affected. After the delivery of the crossover litter, the F0 control and 1% molecule mice were killed and necropsied. Male body weight was not affected by molecule consumption, though adjusted liver weight was increased by nearly 35%, and seminal vesicle weight was reduced by nearly 30%. Sperm endpoints were unchanged. Female body weight was reduced by nearly 10%, while adjusted liver weight was increased by nearly 14%. The estrous cycle was not evaluated in these animals. No second generation evaluation was performed for the molecule. In summary, consumption of almost 1.5 g/kg/day of the molecule by mice increased liver weight, reduced female body weight, and reduced fertility of both males and females. Lower levels of consumption were without effect on fertility.

input: Can you indicate the National Toxicology Program Studies for the molecule InChI=1S/C14H21N3O3S/c1-12-6-8-13(9-7-12)21(19,20)16-14(18)15-17-10-4-2-3-5-11-17/h6-9H,2-5,10-11H2,1H3,(H2,15,16,18)?
output: The molecule was administered in feed to Fischer 344 rats and B6C3F1 mice at doses of either 5,000 or 10,000 ppm for 103 weeks. Survival rates for dosed rats were higher than those for matched controls, allowing for the development of late appearing tumors. Survival rates for mice were lower, especially for dosed females, but were still adequate for tumor development. No statistically significant increase in tumor incidence was observed in dosed animals compared to controls. Tolazamide was not found to be carcinogenic for the tested animals.

input: What is the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule called InChI=1S/C9H13NO3/c1-10-5-9(13)6-2-3-7(11)8(12)4-6/h2-4,9-13H,5H2,1H3/t9-/m0/s1?
output: The molecule was tested in toxicology and carcinogenesis studies by exposing groups of F344/N rats and B6C3Fl mice of each sex to an aerosol containing the compound for 2 years. In the 2-year studies, groups of 60 rats of each sex were exposed to different concentrations of the molecule, while groups of 60 mice of each sex were exposed to other concentrations. The exposure levels used in these studies were higher than typical therapeutic doses but lower than the maximum tolerated dose. The results showed no carcinogenic effects in rats or mice exposed to the compound for 2 years. However, the studies were considered inadequate for assessing carcinogenic activity due to the low concentrations used.

input: What is the National Toxicology Program Studies associated with the molecule InChI=1S/C2H5Cl/c1-2-3/h2H2,1H3?
output: The molecule was tested for toxicology and carcinogenesis by exposing groups of rats and mice to the compound through inhalation for various durations over a period of 2 years. The survival rates of the exposed groups were significantly lower than the control groups, with female mice primarily succumbing to uterine carcinomas and male mice dying early due to urinary tract infections. There was some evidence of carcinogenic activity in male rats, with skin neoplasms observed, and in female rats, with brain astrocytomas noted. The study in male mice was deemed inadequate, but there was an increased incidence of lung neoplasms. Female mice showed clear evidence of carcinogenic activity, with uterine carcinomas and a slight increase in liver neoplasms.

input: I would like to know the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule referred to as InChI=1S/C3H6Cl2/c1-3(5)2-4/h3H,2H2,1H3.
output: The molecule was administered in corn oil by gavage to groups of rats and mice at various doses for 103 weeks. Male F344/N rats showed no evidence of carcinogenicity at lower doses. Female rats exhibited equivocal evidence of carcinogenicity at higher doses, with marginally increased adenocarcinomas in the mammary gland. Male and female B6C3F1 mice showed some evidence of carcinogenicity, with increased incidences of hepatocellular neoplasms, primarily adenomas.

input: Please tell me the National Toxicology Program Studies of the compound named JHBKHLUZVFWLAG-UHFFFAOYSA-N.
output: The molecule was tested for its effects on fertility & reproduction in Swiss CD-1 mice using the continuous breeding protocol. Male & female mice (F0) were continuously exposed for a 7 day precohabitation & a 98 day cohabitation period to the molecule at levels of 0.028, 0.072, & 0.18% /weight/volume/ in the diet. Treatment at 0.18% was significantly more toxic than anticipated. Nineteen of the 20 high-dose females died or were humanely sacrificed & almost all of these deaths occurred at parturition. None of the males died. In the 0.072% group, a 9% decr in the number of live pups/litter was noted; no changes were observed in pup weights, proportion of male pups, or days to deliver each litter. The determination of the affected sex was not conducted, given the small change in litter size. At terminal sacrifice, the avg liver weight & the liver-to-body weight ratio in F0 males exposed to 0.18% were almost twice the control values. In the F1 generation, liver & kidneys were enlarged in both sexes exposed to 0.072%. Sperm abnormalities were greater in the 0.18% group by 40%, compared to controls. Seminal vesicle weight was increased in the high-dose-treated males. The second generation was reared consuming control diet, or diet with 0.072%. At sexual maturity, there was no difference in mating, litter size, pup weight, or dam weight. At F1 necropsy, there was an incr in the absolute & relative weights of liver, kidneys, & testis in the 0.072% group, with similar increases in female liver & kidneys weights. There was no change in F1 female estrual cycle parameters. Under the present experimental conditions, the molecule exerted mild reproductive toxicity in the presence of considerable systemic toxicity. Thus, the molecule is a reproductive toxicant in the presence of significant systemic toxicity.

input: What is the value of the National Toxicology Program Studies for the molecule OCc1ccco1?
output: The molecule was tested on groups of 50 male and 50 female F344/N rats and groups of 50 male and 50 female mice. They were exposed to furfuryl alcohol by inhalation, 6 hr/day 5 days/wk for 105 wk at concentrations of 0, 2, 8 or 32 ppm. The results showed evidence of carcinogenic activity in male F344/N rats with increased incidences of combined neoplasms of the nose. There was equivocal evidence of carcinogenic activity in female F344/N rats with marginally increased incidences of neoplasms of the nose and renal tubule. Carcinogenic activity was observed in male B6C3F1 mice with increased incidences of renal tubule neoplasms. However, there was no evidence of carcinogenic activity in female B6C3F1 mice exposed to 2, 8 or 32 ppm.

input: Can you share the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule known as RWGFKTVRMDUZSP-UHFFFAOYSA-N?
output: The molecule cumene vapor was administered to groups of five male and five female F344/N rats at concentrations of 0, 250, 500, 1,000, 2,000, or 4,000 ppm for 6 hours plus T90 (12 minutes) per day, 5 days per week for 16 days. Rats exposed to 4,000 ppm died on day 1, and two male and three female rats exposed to 2,000 ppm died by day 4. Mean body weights of rats exposed to 2,000 ppm were significantly lower than those of the chamber controls. Rats exposed to 2,000 ppm that died early exhibited severe lethargy following daily exposure. Liver and kidney weights of all exposed groups were increased. Males exposed to concentrations of 250 to 2,000 ppm showed accumulation of minimal to mild hyaline droplets in the renal tubular cortex.

input: Can you provide the National Toxicology Program Studies for the substance named buta-1,3-diene?
output:
The molecule was tested on male and female B6C3F1 mice by exposing them to different concentrations of the chemical for 6 hours a day, 5 days a week. The study was planned for 103 weeks but had to be stopped early due to declining survival rates caused by neoplasia. 

Under these conditions, there was clear evidence of carcinogenicity in both male and female B6C3F1 mice. This was shown by increased incidences and early induction of various types of tumors in different organs in both males and females.

input: I would like to know the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule referred to as JRBJSXQPQWSCCF-UHFFFAOYSA-N.
output: The molecule was administered in drinking water at various concentrations to F344/N rats for 21 months. input: Could you specify the National Toxicology Program Studies of the compound with the name 3-nitrobenzoic acid?
output: The molecule exhibited testicular atrophy and reduced sperm count in both F344 rats and B6C3F1 mice during a 90-day pre-chronic study. Data from a 2-week dose-range-finding study were used to set exposure concentrations for a continuous cohabitation study at 0.35, 0.75, and 1.5% in feed. The estimated daily dosages were approximately 0.5, 1.3, and 2.8 g/kg/day based on mean feed consumption and body weight. During the study, several animals died from various causes, but there was no clear relationship to the exposure. Postpartum dam weights in the middle and high dose groups were lower by approximately 5-8% and 12-14% compared to controls, respectively. Male body weights were reduced by around 9% in the high dose group. Reproductive performance was impaired, with mice in the middle and high dose groups delivering approximately 10% and 27% fewer pups per litter, respectively. Pup mortality before weaning was increased at the high dose, with surviving pups weighing 30-40% less than controls. A crossover test conducted with the control and high dose mice showed a 33% reduction in the number of mated females delivering a litter in the group containing treated females. Female body weight was reduced by 13% in the high dose group, while male body weight was reduced by around 10%. The F1 mice from all dose groups exhibited reduced live pup numbers and adjusted pup weight. After the F2 litters were evaluated, female body weight was reduced by 5% and 23% in the middle and high dose groups, respectively. Male body weight was reduced by 10% and 18% in the middle and high dose groups, respectively. Adjusted kidney weight was reduced by nearly 10% at the high dose only. No significant treatment-related microscopic lesions were noted in the reproductive organs of these animals. Thus, the molecule reduced weight gain in adults and caused significant reproductive toxicity in both generations, with females appearing more sensitive than males. Non-reproductive toxicities such as organ weight changes and microscopic lesions were not marked.
