input: I'm interested in knowing the National Toxicology Program Studies of CCCCCOC(=O)c1ccccc1C(=O)OCCCCC. Could you provide that?
output: The molecule Di-N-pentylphthalate (DPP) was tested using the Fertility Assessment by Continuous Breeding (FACB) protocol in Swiss CD-1 mice as part of a structure-activity evaluation of a variety of phthalates. Body weights, food & water consumptions, & clinical signs in a dose-range-finding study were used to set doses for the main study of 0.0, 0.5, 1.25, & 2.50% in feed. Measured feed consumption was increased by 8-35% at the highest concn, but was unchanged in other DPP groups. Based on these measures, these concns produced calculated consumption estimates of nearly =0.76, 2.16, & 4.8 g/kg/day. During the continuous breeding phase (Task 2), all control pairs had at least 1 litter, while only 4 of 19 low dose pairs delivered a litter, & no middle dose or high dose pairs delivered a litter. In the 7 litters delivered at the low dose, the number of live pups/litter was reduced from control values by 90%; there were insufficient live pups to calculate pup weights adjusted for body weight. At the end of Task 2, the control & high dose mice were cross-mated. The groups that contained either treated males, or treated females, gave birth to no live young, while 61% of cohabited control pairs bore live young. The F0 control & high dose mice were necropsied after the crossover mating trial. The treated females weighed 9% less than their controls, while body-weight-adjusted liver weight was 56% greater than controls, & adjusted kidney weight was 12% less. Treated males weighed 10% less than controls, while adjusted liver weight was 55% greater. In males, adjusted kidney weights, seminal vesicles, & epididymal weights were reduced by 30%, 29% & 19% respectively. At the high dose, absolute testis weight was decreased by 78%, & there were no detectable epididymal sperm. A second generation evaluation was not performed for DPP. Thus, DPP at these concns sharply reduced litter size & number of litters/pair in the F0 mice.

input: Please tell me the National Toxicology Program Studies of the compound named MGFYIUFZLHCRTH-UHFFFAOYSA-N.
output: The molecule was tested in bioassays for carcinogenicity using F344 rats and B6C3F1 mice. The molecule was mixed in respective diets and administered ad libitum. It was tested in rats at various concentrations for different time periods. The molecule was also tested in mice at different concentrations for 18 months. The number of animals used in the tests varied for each dose group. The molecule was shown to be carcinogenic to the urinary tracts of both rats and mice at higher doses tested. Lower doses did not induce significant numbers of such lesions.

input: I would like to know the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule referred to as QUKGYYKBILRGFE-UHFFFAOYSA-N.
output: The molecule benzyl acetate >99% pure was administered in corn oil by gavage to groups of 50 male and 50 female F344/N rats at doses of 0, 250, or 500 mg/kg body weight and to groups of 50 male and 50 female B6C3F1 mice at doses of 0, 500, or 1000 mg/kg once daily five days per week for 103 weeks. Under the conditions of these gavage studies, benzyl acetate increased the incidence of acinar cell adenomas of the exocrine pancreas in male F344/N rats; the gavage vehicle may have been a contributing factor. There was no evidence of carcinogenicity for female F344/N rats. For male and female B6C3F1 mice, there was some evidence of carcinogenicity in that benzyl acetate caused an increased incidences of hepatocellular adenomas and squamous cell neoplasms of the forestomach.

input: For the molecule named FDZZZRQASAIRJF-UHFFFAOYSA-M, could you provide its National Toxicology Program Studies?
output: The molecule malachite green chloride was administered to male and female F344/N Nctr BR rats and B6C3F1/Nctr BR (C57BL/6N x C3H/HeN MTV-) mice in feed for 28 days. Animals were assessed for clinical pathology and histopathology. Genetic toxicity studies were conducted in vitro in Salmonella typhimurium and in vivo in rat bone marrow erythrocytes and mouse peripheral blood erythrocytes. Groups of rats and mice were fed diets containing various concentrations of malachite green chloride for the duration of the study. All animals survived until the end of the study. In the malachite green chloride study, male rats in the 1,200 ppm group had significantly lower body weight gain compared to controls. Female rats and mice in the 1,200 ppm groups, as well as female rats and mice in the 600 and 1,200 ppm groups, had significantly lower body weight gains compared to controls. Feed consumption by all exposed groups was similar to controls. Exposure to malachite green chloride resulted in average daily doses ranging from 3 to 250 mg/kg body weight. Female rats exposed to malachite green chloride showed a significant increase in gamma-glutamyltransferase activity at 1,200 ppm.

input: Can you provide the National Toxicology Program Studies for the substance named InChI=1S/C6H6Cl2N2/c7-4-1-3(9)2-5(8)6(4)10/h1-2H,9-10H2?
output: The molecule was tested in a carcinogenesis bioassay in F344 rats and B6C3F1 mice. Male rats were fed 1,000 or 2,000 ppm, while female rats were fed 2,000 or 6,000 ppm for 103 weeks. Mice were fed 1,000 or 3,000 ppm for 103 weeks. Controls consisted of untreated rats and mice. The molecule was carcinogenic for male and female B6C3Fl mice, causing increased incidences of hepatocellular adenomas and carcinomas, and for male B6C3F1 mice, causing an increased incidence of hepatocellular adenomas. It was not carcinogenic for male or female F344 rats. Levels of Evidence of Carcinogenicity: Male Rats: Negative; Female Rats: Negative; Male Mice: Positive; Female Mice: Positive.

input: Tell me the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule QUIMTLZDMCNYGY-UHFFFAOYSA-N, please.

input: Tell me the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule GNRSAWUEBMWBQH-UHFFFAOYSA-N, please.
output: The molecule was tested on male and female F344/N rats and B6C3F1 mice through inhalation for a period of 2 years. In the 2-year study on rats, groups of 65 male and 65 female F344/N rats were exposed to varying concentrations of the molecule for 6 hours a day, 5 days a week for 104 weeks. In the 2-year study on mice, groups of 74 to 79 B6C3F1 mice were exposed to different concentrations of the molecule for the same duration. The results showed some evidence of carcinogenic activity of the molecule in male F344/N rats, as indicated by increased incidences of specific types of tumors. Similarly, there was some evidence of carcinogenic activity in female F344/N rats. However, there was no evidence of carcinogenic activity in male B6C3Fl mice. In female B6C3Fl mice, there was equivocal evidence of carcinogenic activity based on slightly increased tumor incidences.

input: I'm interested in knowing the National Toxicology Program Studies of prop-2-enyl 3-methylbutanoate. Could you provide that?
output: The molecule was administered in corn oil by gavage to groups of 50 male and 50 female F344/N rats and to groups of 50 male and 50 female B6C3F1 mice at doses of 31 or 62 mg/kg. Doses were administered five times per week for 103 weeks. Groups of 50 rats and 50 mice of each sex received corn oil by gavage on the same dosing schedule and served as vehicle controls. Under the conditions of these studies, the molecule caused mononuclear cell leukemia in male F344/N rats and lymphoma in female B6C3F1 mice.

The molecule was administered in feed to groups of F344/N rats and B6C3F1 mice of each sex for 2 years. Doses for the 2 year studies included diets containing 0, 25,000 or 50,000 ppm of the molecule for up to 103 weeks. Under the conditions of these 2 year feed studies, there was equivocal evidence of carcinogenicity in male F344/N rats based on finding pheochromocytomas of the adrenal medulla. There was no evidence of carcinogenic activity for the molecule in female F344/N rats or in male or female B6C3F1 mice given 25,000 or 50,000 ppm.

input: Can you provide the National Toxicology Program Studies for the substance named O=[As][O-].[Na+]?
output: The molecule was selected for immunotoxicity studies using female B6C3f1 mice. The purpose of the range-finding study was to determine the doses of the molecule to be used in an immuntoxicology protocol. The range-finding studies were conducted in female B6C3F1 mice. The animals were administered the molecule as a pellet implanted subcutaneously. The pellets were prepared using 1, 3 and 6 mg/pellet as recommended by the producer to obtain the desired blood levels of 100, 300 and 600 ng/ml. These doses proved highly toxic and the pellets were then prepared at 0.01, 0.03 and 0.06 mg/pellet. Two studies were carried out in completing the range-finding protocol. The pellets were implanted on day 1 and the assay evaluations were performed on day 15. Dose levels of 0.01, 0.03 and 0.06 mg/pellet were used; however, the high dose of 0.06 mg/pellet resulted in the death of the mice. The results of the range-finding studies demonstrate that, in the female B6C3F1 mouse, exposure to the molecule, administered by a subcutaneous implanted pellet for a 14-day exposure at doses of 0.06 or greater, produced overt toxicity and death of the animals. Exposure to lower doses of the molecule (0.01 and 0.03 mg/pellet) did not result in significant changes in body weight, change in body weight gain, erythrocyte number, hemoglobin, hematocrit, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration, reticulocytes or leukocyte number. A slight, but significant decrease was seen in the mean corpuscular volume and mean corpuscular hemoglobin. Exposure to lower doses of the molecule (0.01 and 0.03 mg/pellet) did not result in significant changes in liver, spleen, thymus or kidney weight when the data were expressed as absolute weight (mg) or as percent body weight. A significant decrease was seen in the lung absolute weight (22.6%) but not in the percent body weight. Exposure to lower doses of the molecule (0.01 and 0.03 mg/pellet) did not produce significant changes in the antibody-forming cell response to the T-dependent antigen, sheep erythrocytes, expressed as IgM AFC/10, while the IgM AFC/spleen did show a significant increase at 0.03 mg/pellet (49.2%). In the surface marker absolute values, no effects were observed in the number of B cells, T cells or CD8+ cells, but a significant decrease in the CD4+ cells (12.3%) was seen. Exposure to lower doses of the molecule (0.01 and 0.03 mg/pellet) did not result in significant changes in the mixed leukocyte response (MLR) or natural killer (NK) cell activity. Based on the overall negative toxicological and immunological results of this range-finding study, the test article, the molecule, will not be pursued as an expanded protocol.

input: Can you provide the National Toxicology Program Studies for the substance named [Na+].[O-][Cl+2]([O-])[O-]?
output: The molecule was administered to groups of 10 male and 10 female rats in their drinking water at various concentrations for 3 weeks. The rats were exposed to doses ranging from 0 to 2,000 mg/L, equivalent to different daily doses based on body weight. All rats survived the study, with similar body weights and water consumption compared to control groups. A decrease in segmented neutrophil counts was observed in male and female rats on specific days. Heart weights were reduced in males exposed to the highest concentration. Thyroid gland follicular cell hypertrophy was increased in males and females exposed to concentrations of 500 mg/L or higher.

input: Given the molecule named IOEJYZSZYUROLN-UHFFFAOYSA-M, could you provide its National Toxicology Program Studies?
output: The molecule was administered in feed to F344 rats and B6C3Fl mice. Groups of 50 rats of each sex were given the molecule at doses of either 1,250 or 2,500 ppm for 104 weeks. Groups of 50 mice of each sex were given the molecule at doses of either 500 or 4,000 ppm for 108 or 109 weeks. Matched controls consisted of 16 untreated male rats, 20 untreated female rats, and 20 untreated mice of each sex. All surviving rats and mice were sacrificed at the end of administration. It is concluded that under the conditions of this bioassay, the molecule was not carcinogenic for F344 rats or B6C3Fl mice of either sex. Levels of Evidence of Carcinogenicity: Male Rats: Negative; Female Rats: Negative; Male Mice: Negative; Female Mice: Negative.

input: I would like to know the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule referred to as O=C(O)C(Cl)Br.
output: The molecule was evaluated for potential toxicity using a short-term reproductive and developmental toxicity screen to identify the most sensitive physiologic process to exposure. A dose range-finding study was conducted at concentrations in the drinking water for two weeks, with a higher top dose selected for the main study. The main study included male and female rats exposed to different dose levels, with BrdU treatment included to assess cell turnover. During the treatment period, no clinical signs of general toxicity were noted, and there were no treatment-related effects on body weights or feed consumption. Water consumption decreased at higher doses, and some clinical chemistry and hematology endpoints showed minor changes. Organ weights and ratios were comparable, with some minor increases noted in liver-to-body weight ratios. Treatment-related findings included changes in reproductive parameters, such as decreases in total implants and live fetuses per litter in females at the highest dose. Overall, the results suggest that the molecule is taste-aversive and a general toxicant at the highest dose, affecting reproductive function in females.

input: Would you be able to tell me the National Toxicology Program Studies of the molecule KJPRLNWUNMBNBZ-QPJJXVBHSA-N?
output: The molecule was administered to groups of male and female B6C3F1 mice at concentrations of 1,000, 2,100, or 4,100 ppm for 2 years. Additional groups received untreated feed or feed with placebo microcapsules. Average daily doses ranged from 125 to 550 mg/kg. Survival of males in the 2,100 ppm group was lower than that of the vehicle control group. Mean body weights of exposed mice were generally lower than those of controls. Olfactory epithelial pigmentation was significantly higher in exposed males and females compared to controls. No neoplasms were attributed to exposure to the molecule.

input: For the molecule identified as O=NN([O-])c1ccccc1.[NH4+], what is its National Toxicology Program Studies?
output: The molecule was administered in the feed, at either of two concentrations, to groups of 49 or 50 male and 50 female animals of each species. The time-weighted average high and low dietary concentrations of the molecule were, respectively, 0.30 and 0.15 percent for male and female rats, and 0.4 and 0.2 percent for male and female mice. After a 78 week period of compound administration, observation of the rats continued for an additional period of up to 28 weeks and observation of the mice continued for an additional period of up to 18 weeks. For each species, 50 animals of each sex were placed on test as controls and fed only the basal diet. Among both sexes of rats and mice there was a significant positive association between the dose of the molecule administered and mortality. There were significant positive associations between the concentrations of the molecule administered to male and female rats and the incidences of squamous cell carcinomas of the forestomach, hepatocellular carcinomas and neoplastic nodules, and hemangiosarcomas. When a binomial distribution and a spontaneous incidence rate corresponding to the appropriate historical control incidence were assumed, the incidences of auditory sebaceous gland neoplasms in female rats and female mice were significant. There were significant positive associations between the concentrations administered and the incidences of hepatocellular carcinomas in female mice, the incidences of hemangiosarcomas in both sexes of mice, and the incidence of Harderian gland adenomas in both sexes of mice.

input: I'm interested in knowing the National Toxicology Program Studies of InChI=1S/C10H13N5O3S/c11-10-13-8-7(9(19)14-10)12-3-15(8)6-1-4(17)5(2-16)18-6/h3-6,16-17H,1-2H2,(H3,11,13,14,19)/t4-,5+,6+/m0/s1. Could you provide that?
output: The molecule was administered to Sprague-Dawley rats and B6C3F1 mice by intraperitoneal injection. Rats were given doses of either 3.5 or 7 mg/kg body weight three times per week for 52 weeks, while mice were given doses of 2 or 4 mg/kg. Additional groups of mice were administered 1 mg/kg due to severe toxicity at the high dose. The molecule was toxic to rats at the doses used in the study, resulting in lower body weights and early mortality in the high-dose groups. In mice, the molecule was toxic at the doses selected, with high mortality rates. Carcinomas of the ear canal were statistically significant in both male and female rats. In conclusion, the molecule was carcinogenic in rats, particularly in females, but the survival rates and procedural issues in mice did not allow for a determination of its carcinogenic potential in that species.

input: Could you specify the National Toxicology Program Studies of the compound with the name TZBJGXHYKVUXJN-UHFFFAOYSA-N?
output: The molecule was studied under an interagency agreement between NIEHS and NCTR to assess its effects on the immune system. It was administered in feed at doses ranging from 5 to 1250 PPM to male and female Sprague Dawley rats. The F0 generation females received the molecule for 65 days starting 7 days into gestation, while the F1 generation males and females were exposed in utero for 14 days and postpartum until day 77. Exposure led to a decrease in terminal body weight in F1 generation males and females at the highest dose. A significant increase in relative spleen weight was observed in F1 generation males and females. Hematology data showed slight decreases in white blood cell count, platelet count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit in F1 generation rats. Genistein exposure resulted in a dose-dependent decrease in bone marrow cell number and colony-forming units in F1 generation males, while F1 generation females showed a decrease in cells/femur. An increase in splenic B cells and T cell subsets was observed in F1 generation rats. In the spleen AFC response to sheep erythrocytes, an increase in IgM AFC was seen in F1 generation females. Stimulation with anti-CD3 receptor led to an increase in proliferation in spleen cells from F1 generation rats. Natural killer cell activity increased in F0 generation females at 250 and 1250 PPM doses. Overall, exposure to the molecule did not impact the immunocompetence of F0 generation females, but led to increased T cell number and function in F1 generation rats.

input: Can you provide the National Toxicology Program Studies for the substance named 1-[(E)-(5-nitrofuran-2-yl)methylideneamino]imidazolidine-2,4-dione?

input: For the molecule identified as QGLZXHRNAYXIBU-WEVVVXLNSA-N, what is its National Toxicology Program Studies?

Survival rates were not significantly affected in dosed groups of either rats or mice, with rates of 72% or greater in all dosed or control groups at week 90. As with previous extrapolations, production rates fail to account for estimated oceanic strengths of the chemical. It is suggested that indirect production of the molecule via microbial decay of seaweed iodocarbons may fill this gap. input: What is the value of the Plant Concentrations for the molecule CC(C)OP(C)(=O)OC(C)C?
output: The molecule is diisopropyl methylphosphonate. Although no concns were reported, some uptake of diisopropyl methylphosphonate does appear to occur in plants. Sugar beet, carrot, wheat, and bean plants grown both hydroponically and in soil showed slight bioconcentration relative to the growth medium. Wheat leaves (soil grown) had a BCF of 11.0, the highest of all the plants(3). Repeated application of irrigation water contaminated with diisopropyl methylphosphonate may result in the absorption, translocation, and bioconcentration of diisopropyl methylphosphonate in plant tissue(2). When applied to sugar beet leaves, diisopropyl methylphosphonate was absorbed and translocated to all parts of the plant (except new leaves) after 72 hours. However, diisopropyl methylphosphonate did not translocate when applied to corn leaves. The observation that bioconcentration in plants is low may be a result of metabolism, which is known to occur in mammals and birds(1,4).

input: Could you specify the Plant Concentrations of the compound with the name 1-methoxy-4-[2,2,2-trichloro-1-(4-methoxyphenyl)ethyl]benzene?

input: Would you be able to tell me the Soil AdsorptionMobility of the molecule APQHKWPGGHMYKJ-UHFFFAOYSA-N?
output: The molecule tributyltin did not leach from various soils (clay, sand, topsoil, silt) over 16 weeks. Tributyltin strongly binds to sediment with a distribution constant of 2180 at 20 °C. Minimal release of tributyltin or inorganic tin occurred from unshaken sediment in 10 months. Studies indicate that tributyltin does not significantly adsorb to suspended particulate matter and is mainly associated with the dissolved fraction of estuarine water. Addition of humic acids or kaolin clay material does not greatly impact the measured bis(tributyltin) BCF in mussels, suggesting weak binding of bis(tributyltin) species to these materials. Adsorption studies on a variety of sorbents show sorption coefficients ranging from 110 to 350,000 l/kg, with most coefficients around 1,000 l/kg. Adsorption is rapid (hours) and reversible. In a 278-day marine mesocosm experiment, the transport rate from water to sediment was 0.045/day. The distribution coefficient between dissolved state and particulate matter was 60,000 (standard deviation 30,000) between days 2-19. Other researchers found distribution constants for adsorption of tributyltin to particulate matter and sediment ranging from 3400-9300 l/kg and 200-55,000 l/kg, respectively, depending on sediment type and location. The Freundlich parameters for tributyl tin to sediment were log k = 1.07 and 1/n = 0.359. In soil microcosm experiments, small releases of bis(tributyltin) oxide from wood treated with the compound migrated >10 cm from the wood, with 86% of the compound within 5 cm of the wood; no compound was detected below 10 cm or in groundwater at the bottom of the microcosm chamber. These findings suggest that bis(tributyltin) oxide can strongly bind to soil and sediment, but adsorption to suspended particulate and humic matter may be weaker.

input: Can you provide the Toxicity for the substance named FOCAUTSVDIKZOP-UHFFFAOYSA-N?
output: The molecule chloroacetic acid (MCA) is a solid. Most of the chloroacetic acid produced is used to manufacture several hundred thousand tons annually of carboxymethyl cellulose. Another major application is the production of herbicides based on arylhydroxyacetic acids. The anticipated acute and chronic human health hazards posed by MCA are effects on the cardiac system, the central nervous system, and kidneys. In addition, MCA is highly corrosive and irritating to the eyes, skin and respiratory tract. Acute dermal exposure of workers to MCA may result in death even after rapid and extensive washing of the skin area. The effects may be delayed. The biochemical mechanism of action resulting in death is not understood. Contributing factors apparently believed to be involved are: (i) the inhibition of the tricarboxylic acid cycle decreasing cellular energy supply and increasing acidosis with glycolic acid and oxalate production, and; (ii) effects on cellular components where sulfhydryl groups are critical for normal biological activity. Both of these effects may contribute to CNS, cardiovascular, renal and hepatic effects. In addition, the metabolites glycolic acid and oxalate may contribute to CNS and renal toxicity. A case of joint deformity reported after the use of a preparation containing MCA for topical wart treatment. MCA did not induce DNA strand breaks in human CCRF-CEM cells. Indications: Description: Premature ventricular extrasystoles and ventricular tachycardia; supraventricular arrhythmia; maintenance of sinus rhythm after cardioversion of atrial flutter or fibrillation. HUMAN EXPOSURE: Main risks and target organs: Cardio-toxicity is the main risk of the molecule poisoning. The molecule may induce central nervous system symptoms. Symptoms appear usually within 2 to 4 hours and may include: cardiovascular symptoms: hypotension, cardiogenic shock, cardiac arrest. ECG may show: decrease of T wave; prolongation of QT and QRS intervals; atrioventricular block; ventricular dysrhythmia (torsade de pointes). Neurological symptoms: tinnitus, drowsiness, syncope, coma, convulsion, blurred vision and diplopia. Respiratory symptoms: hypoventilation and apnea. Cardiotoxicity may be enhanced if other cardiotoxic drugs have been ingested (antiarrhythmic drugs, tricyclic antidepressants). Parenteral exposure: After IV administration symptoms appear more rapidly. Chronic poisoning: Ingestion: The most relevant symptoms of chronic poisoning are: ECG disturbances; syncope due to ventricular dysrhythmia, (torsade de pointes) and cinchonism gastrointestinal disturbances Course, prognosis, cause of death: The usual course of the molecule poisoning is dominated by the cardiovascular disturbances which usually occur within 2 to 4 first hours but may first appear as late as 12 hours after exposure (and perhaps even later after ingestion of a slow- release preparation). Symptoms may last for 24 to 36 hours. Patients who survive 48 hours after acute poisoning are likely to recover. Death may result from cardiac arrest by asystole or electromechanical dissociation and, rarely, by ventricular fibrillation. Systematic description of clinical effects: Cardiovascular: Acute: Cardiovascular symptoms are the major features of the molecule toxicity. Tachycardia due to anticholinergic effects is usually observed initially or in moderate intoxication. In severe intoxication, bradycardia due to atrioventricular block may occur. Hypotension and shock: hypotension due to peripheral vasodilation is common. In severe intoxication, cardiogenic shock with increased central venous pressure is usually observed and is related to decreased cardiac contractility. Cardiac arrest may occur, which may be related to electromechanical dissociation, ventricular dysrhythmia or asystole. Cardiac dysrhythmias are common and may include: atrioventricular block, idioventricular rhythm, ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation, torsades de pointes. ECG changes are always present in symptomatic intoxication: repolarization abnormalities, decreased T wave, increase of U wave, prolongation of QT and PR intervals, widening of QRS complexes (> 0.08 sec), atrioventricular block. Syncope due to torsade de pointes may occur. Chronic: ECG changes with repolarization abnormalities, decreased T wave and increase of QT interval are a common feature during the molecule therapy. Syncope is related to transient torsade de pointes and occurs in 1 to 8% of patients receiving the molecule. The occurrence of torsade de pointes is not correlated with plasma the molecule levels but is favored by an increase in the QT interval. Respiratory: Acute: Respiratory depression or apnea is mostly associated with severe cardiac disturbances such as shock or ventricular dysrhythmia. Pulmonary edema with normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure following an attempted suicide has been documented. Neurological: CNS: Acute: Drowsiness, delirium, coma and convulsions may appear without cardiac symptoms. However, cardiac failure should always be considered when CNS symptoms appear. Cinchonism may sometimes appear. Chronic: Cinchonism. Delirium has been reported. Peripheral nervous system: Chronic: The molecule can potentiate the neuromuscular blocking action of some skeletal muscle relaxants and may cause the return of respiratory paralysis if it is given shortly after recovery from neuromuscular blockade. Autonomic nervous system: Acute: The molecule has an anticholinergic effect. However, this effect is usually limited to the vagal system. Skeletal and smooth muscle: Chronic: An increase in serum concentrations of skeletal muscle enzymes has been reported in a man treated with the molecule. Gastrointestinal: Acute: Nausea and vomiting may occur. Chronic: Gastrointestinal toxicity (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and colic) is the most frequent side effect of the molecule. Hepatic: Chronic: Hepatotoxicity has been reported, with an increase in serum concentrations of transaminases, LDH, alkaline phosphatase, and cholestasis. Renal: Acute: No direct nephrotoxic effect has been reported. Acute renal failure related to cardiogenic shock may occur. Dermatological: Chronic: Skin lesions have been attributed to the use of the molecule and include skin rash, photosensitivity and lichen planus. Eye, ear, nose, throat: local effects: Acute: Cinchonism is rarely observed in acute poisonings. Toxic amblyopia, scotoma and impaired color perception may occur at toxic doses. Chronic: Chronic cumulative overdose may cause cinchonism: headache, tinnitus, vertigo, mydriasis, blurred vision, diplopia, photophobia, deafness, and corneal deposits have been reported in a patient who took the molecule for two years. Hematological: Chronic: Thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia of immunologic origins have been reported. Immunological: Chronic: The molecule may cause several immunologic mediated reactions: thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, angioneurotic edema, skin rash, fever. Metabolic: Acid-base disturbances: Acute: Metabolic acidosis may occur in severe intoxication with shock. Fluid and electrolyte disturbances: Acute: Hypokalemia is frequently observed. Special risks: Pregnancy: Chronic: The molecule has been implicated as a cause of cranial nerve damage to the fetus at doses much larger than those needed to treat arrhythmias. In a neonate born to a woman taking the molecule throughout pregnancy, serum levels were equal to that of the mother. The child's ECG was normal and there was no evidence of teratogenicity. Breast-feeding: Chronic: The molecule is present in breast milk at levels slightly lower than serum levels. The dose of the molecule received by an infant taking 1l of milk would be below therapeutic doses. However, breast-feeding is not recommended because of potential the molecule accumulation in the immature newborn liver.

Shortness of breath can be alleviated with bronchodilators, which open up the bronchial tubes for better airflow. In severe cases of asbestosis, supplemental oxygen may be necessary. Productive cough can be managed with humidifiers and chest percussion. While asbestosis can be treated, it cannot be cured.

This Henry's Law constant indicates that the molecule is expected to be essentially nonvolatile from moist soil and water surfaces. The molecule is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon an estimated vapor pressure of 5.4X10-15 mm Hg, determined from a fragment constant method.
